Sentence: Immunology is the study of the immune system and how it defends the body against harmful agents like pathogens, toxins, and cancer cells.
Label: Definition

Sentence: The immune system consists of organs, cells, and molecules that work together to protect the body from infections.
Label: Explanation

Sentence: Key components of the immune system include white blood cells, antibodies, lymph nodes, and the spleen.
Label: Explanation

Sentence: The immune system can be classified into innate immunity, which provides immediate defense, and adaptive immunity, which develops over time.
Label: Explanation

Sentence: Innate immunity includes physical barriers like skin and mucous membranes, as well as cellular defenses like macrophages and neutrophils.
Label: Explanation

Sentence: Adaptive immunity involves specialized cells, such as T cells and B cells, that recognize and attack specific pathogens.
Label: Clarification

Sentence: Immunological memory allows the body to respond more efficiently to subsequent infections by the same pathogen.
Label: Cause and Effect

Sentence: The immune system is crucial in identifying and eliminating pathogens, preventing infections, and even detecting and destroying cancer cells.
Label: Purpose

Sentence: Vaccination is a way of enhancing the adaptive immune system by introducing harmless antigens that trigger an immune response.
Label: Purpose

Sentence: Immunodeficiencies, such as HIV/AIDS, occur when the immune system is weakened, making the body more susceptible to infections.
Label: Explanation
